column2: CHAPTER 7 A SIEGE AND BED

column2: The children were sitting in the gloomy banqueting-hall, at the end of one of the long bare wooden tables.

column2: There was now no hope.

column2: Martha had brought in the dinner, and the dinner was invisible, and unfeelable too; for, when they rubbed their hands along the table, they knew but too well that for them there was nothing there BUT table.

column2: How is it the biscuits are here, and all the bread and meat and things have disappeared?'

column2: 'I don't know,' said Cyril after a pause, 'unless it's because WE had them.

column2: Nothing about us has changed.

column2: Everything's in my pocket all right.'

column2: Cyril stood up with a grin of triumph, holding a square piece of bread in his mouth.

column2: Robert captured a slice of mutton, and - but I think I will draw a veil over the rest of this painful scene.

column2: The pudding was, fortunately, a plain suet roly-poly, and in answer to Martha's questions the children all with one accord said that they would NOT have treacle on it - nor jam, nor sugar - 'Just plain, please,' they said.

column2: Martha said, 'Well, I never - what next, I wonder!' and went away.

column2: Then ensued another scene on which I will not dwell, for nobody looks nice picking up slices of suet pudding from the table in its mouth, like a dog. The great thing, after all, was that they had had dinner; and now everyone felt more courage to prepare for the attack that was to be delivered before sunset.

column2: And now they could see all round the castle, and could see, too, that beyond the moat, on every side, the tents of the besieging party were pitched.

column2: 'What a good thing we've got a moat,' he said; 'and what a good thing the drawbridge is up - I should never have known how to work it.'

column2: 'Of course it would be up in a besieged castle.'

column2: 'You see you don't know how long it's been besieged,' said Cyril darkly; 'perhaps most of the brave defenders were killed quite early in the siege and all the provisions eaten, and now there are only a few intrepid survivors - that's us, and we are going to defend it to the death.'
column3: 'You see you don't know how long it's been besieged,' said Cyril darkly; 'perhaps most of the brave defenders were killed quite early in the siege and all the provisions eaten, and now there are only a few intrepid survivors — that's us, and we are going to defend it to the death.'

column2: And there are holes like it in the gate-tower here.'

column2: The children found plenty of strange weapons in the castle, and if they were armed at all it was soon plain that they would be, as Cyril said, 'armed heavily' - for these swords and lances and crossbows were far too weighty even for Cyril's manly strength; and as for the longbows, none of the children could even begin to bend them.

column2: A trumpeter came forward to the edge of the moat, which now seemed very much narrower than at first, and blew the longest and loudest blast they had yet heard.
column3: A trumpeter came forward to the edge of the moat, which now seemed very much narrower than at first, and blew the longest and loudest blast they had yet heard.

column2: When the blaring noise had died away, a man who was with the trumpeter shouted:

column2: 'What ho, within there!' and his voice came plainly to the garrison in the gate-house.

column2: 'Hullo there!' Robert bellowed back at once.

column2: 'In the name of our Lord the King, and of our good lord and trusty leader Sir Wulfric de Talbot, we summon this castle to surrender - on pain of fire and sword and no quarter.

column2: Do ye surrender?'

column3: 'Oh dear!' said Jane; 'don't you think we'd better surrender?'

column2: 'Never!' said Robert; 'we'll have a parley if you like, but we'll never surrender.
column3: 'Never!' said Robert; 'we'll have a parley if you like, but we'll never surrender.

column2: Oh, I'll be a soldier when I grow up - you just see if I don't.
column3: Oh, I'll be a soldier when I grow up — you just see if I don't.

column2: I won't go into the Civil Service, whatever anyone says.'
column3: I won't go into the Civil Service, whatever anyone says.'

column2: 'Let's wave a handkerchief and ask for a parley,' Jane pleaded.
column3: 'Let's wave a handkerchief and ask for a parley,' Jane pleaded.

column2: 'I don't believe the sun's going to set to-night at all.'
column3: 'I don't believe the sun's going to set to night at all.'

column2: 'Give them the water first - the brutes!' said the bloodthirsty Robert.
column3: 'Give them the water first — the brutes!' said the bloodthirsty Robert.

column2: So Anthea tilted the pot over the nearest lead-hole, and poured.
column3: So Anthea tilted the pot over the nearest lead hole, and poured.

column2: They heard a splash below, but no one below seemed to have felt it.
column3: They heard a splash below, but no one below seemed to have felt it.

column2: And again the ram battered the great door.
column3: And again the ram battered the great door.

column2: Anthea paused.
column3: Anthea paused.

column2: 'How idiotic,' said Robert, lying flat on the floor and putting one eye to the lead hole.
column3: 'How idiotic,' said Robert, lying flat on the floor and putting one eye to the lead hole.

column2: 'Of course the holes go straight down into the gate-house - that's for when the enemy has got past the door and the portcullis, and almost all is lost.
column3: 'Of course the holes go straight down into the gate house — that's for when the enemy has got past the door and the portcullis, and almost all is lost.

column2: Here, hand me the pot.' He crawled on to the three-cornered window-ledge in the middle of the wall, and, taking the pot from Anthea, poured the water out through the arrow-slit.
column3: Here, hand me the pot.' He crawled on to the three cornered window ledge in the middle of the wall, and, taking the pot from Anthea, poured the water out through the arrow slit.

column2: And as he began to pour, the noise of the battering-ram and the trampling of the foe and the shouts of 'Surrender!' and 'De Talbot for ever!' all suddenly stopped and went out like the snuff of a candle; the little dark room seemed to whirl round and turn topsy-turvy, and when the children came to themselves there they were safe and sound, in the big front bedroom of their own house - the house with the ornamental nightmare iron-top to the roof.
column3: And as he began to pour, the noise of the battering ram and the trampling of the foe and the shouts of 'Surrender!' and 'De Talbot for ever!' all suddenly stopped and went out like the snuff of a candle; the little dark room seemed to whirl round and turn topsy turvy, and when the children came to themselves there they were safe and sound, in the big front bedroom of their own house — the house with the ornamental nightmare iron top to the roof.

column2: They all crowded to the window and looked out.
column3: They all crowded to the window and looked out.

column2: The moat and the tents and the besieging force were all gone - and there was the garden with its tangle of dahlias and marigolds and asters and late roses, and the spiky iron railings and the quiet white road.
column3: The moat and the tents and the besieging force were all gone — and there was the garden with its tangle of dahlias and marigolds and asters and late roses, and the spiky iron railings and the quiet white road.

column2: Everyone drew a deep breath.
column3: Everyone drew a deep breath.

column2: 'And that's all right!' said Robert. 'I told you so!
column3: 'And that's all right!' said Robert. 'I told you so!

column2: And, I say, we didn't surrender, did we?'
column3: And, I say, we didn't surrender, did we?'

column2: 'Aren't you glad now I wished for a castle?' asked Cyril.
column3: 'Aren't you glad now I wished for a castle?' asked Cyril.

column2: 'I think I am NOW,' said Anthea slowly.
column3: 'I think I am NOW,' said Anthea slowly.

column2: 'But I wouldn't wish for it again, I think, Squirrel dear!'
column3: 'But I wouldn't wish for it again, I think, Squirrel dear!'

column2: 'Oh, it was simply splendid!' said Jane unexpectedly.
column3: 'Oh, it was simply splendid!' said Jane unexpectedly.

column2: 'I wasn't frightened a bit.'
column3: 'I wasn't frightened a bit.'

column2: 'Oh, I say!' Cyril was beginning, but Anthea stopped him.
column3: 'Oh, I say!' Cyril was beginning, but Anthea stopped him.

column2: 'Look here,' she said, 'it's just come into my head.
column3: 'Look here,' she said, 'it's just come into my head.

column2: This is the very first thing we've wished for that hasn't got us into a row.
column3: This is the very first thing we've wished for that hasn't got us into a row.

column2: And there hasn't been the least little scrap of a row about this.
column3: And there hasn't been the least little scrap of a row about this.

column2: Nobody's raging downstairs, we're safe and sound, we've had an awfully jolly day - at least, not jolly exactly, but you know what I mean.
column3: Nobody's raging downstairs, we're safe and sound, we've had an awfully jolly day — at least, not jolly exactly, but you know what I mean.

column2: And we know now how brave Robert is - and Cyril too, of course,' she added hastily, 'and Jane as well.
column3: And we know now how brave Robert is — and Cyril too, of course,' she added hastily, 'and Jane as well.

column2: And we haven't got into a row with a single grown-up.'
column3: And we haven't got into a row with a single grown up.'

column2: The door was opened suddenly and fiercely.
column3: The door was opened suddenly and fiercely.

column2: 'You ought to be ashamed of yourselves,' said the voice of Martha, and they could tell by her voice that she was very angry indeed.
column3: 'You ought to be ashamed of yourselves,' said the voice of Martha, and they could tell by her voice that she was very angry indeed.

column2: 'I thought you couldn't last through the day without getting up to some doggery!
column3: 'I thought you couldn't last through the day without getting up to some doggery!

column2: A person can't take a breath of air on the front doorstep but you must be emptying the wash-hand jug on to their heads!
column3: A person can't take a breath of air on the front doorstep but you must be emptying the wash hand jug on to their heads!

column2: Off you go to bed, the lot of you, and try to get up better children in the morning.
column3: Off you go to bed, the lot of you, and try to get up better children in the morning.

column2: Now then - don't let me have to tell you twice.
column3: Now then — don't let me have to tell you twice.

column2: If I find any of you not in bed in ten minutes I'll let you know it, that's all!
column3: If I find any of you not in bed in ten minutes I'll let you know it, that's all!

column2: A new cap, and everything!'
column3: A new cap, and everything!'

column2: She flounced out amid a disregarded chorus of regrets and apologies.
column3: She flounced out amid a disregarded chorus of regrets and apologies.

column2: The children were very sorry, but really it was not their faults.
column3: The children were very sorry, but really it was not their faults.

column2: You can't help it if you are pouring water on a besieging foe, and your castle suddenly changes into your house - and everything changes with it except the water, and that happens to fall on somebody else's clean cap.
column3: You can't help it if you are pouring water on a besieging foe, and your castle suddenly changes into your house — and everything changes with it except the water, and that happens to fall on somebody else's clean cap.

column2: 'I don't know why the water didn't change into nothing, though,' said Cyril.
column3: 'I don't know why the water didn't change into nothing, though,' said Cyril.

column2: 'Why should it?' asked Robert.
column3: 'Why should it?' asked Robert.

column2: 'Water's water all the world over.' 'I expect the castle well was the same as ours in the stable-yard,' said Jane.
column3: 'Water's water all the world over.' 'I expect the castle well was the same as ours in the stable yard,' said Jane.

column2: And that was really the case.
column3: And that was really the case.

column2: 'I thought we couldn't get through a wish-day without a row,' said Cyril; 'it was much too good to be true.
column3: 'I thought we couldn't get through a wish day without a row,' said Cyril; 'it was much too good to be true.

column2: Come on, Bobs, my military hero.
column3: Come on, Bobs, my military hero.

column2: If we lick into bed sharp she won't be so frumious, and perhaps she'll bong us up some supper.
column3: If we lick into bed sharp she won't be so frumious, and perhaps she'll bong us up some supper.

column2: I'm jolly hungry! Good-night, kids.'
column3: I'm jolly hungry! Good night, kids.'

column2: 'Good-night.
column3: 'Good night.

column2: I hope the castle won't come creeping back in the night,' said Jane.
column3: I hope the castle won't come creeping back in the night,' said Jane.

column2: 'Of course it won't,' said Anthea briskly, 'but Martha will - not in the night, but in a minute.
column3: 'Of course it won't,' said Anthea briskly, 'but Martha will — not in the night, but in a minute.

column2: Here, turn round, I'll get that knot out of your pinafore strings.'
column3: Here, turn round, I'll get that knot out of your pinafore strings.'
